conclusion: Hemispherical Bodies Problem: Normal and Friction Force Analysis
I'll solve this step-by-step by analyzing the forces on each body and using static equilibrium principles.
Body A: hemispherical, mass m, on rough ground
Body B: hemispherical, mass 2m, on rough ground
Body C: hemispherical, mass m, with smooth outer surface, placed between A and B
The coefficient of friction is μ = √3/6, and all bodies have radius R.

premise: Since the bodies are at rest, the net force on each body must be zero.
conclusion: For body C, the smooth outer surface means no friction between C and the other bodies.
Body C experiences: Weight downward: m·g, Normal force from A: N₁, Normal force from B: N₂, Normal force from ground: N₃

premise: For vertical equilibrium of C: N₃ = m·g - (N₁ sin θ₁ + N₂ sin θ₂)
conclusion: N₃ = m·g - (N₁ sin θ₁ + N₂ sin θ₂)

premise: Since all bodies have the same radius R, and A and B are just touching, the centers of the three hemispheres form an equilateral triangle.
For horizontal equilibrium of C: N₁ cos θ₁ = N₂ cos θ₂
Since θ₁ = θ₂, we get N₁ = N₂.

conclusion: For body A (mass m): Weight: m·g downward, Normal force from ground: F, Friction force from ground: f, Force from C: N directed at 30° above horizontal

premise: For horizontal equilibrium of A: f = N·cos(π/6) = N·(√3/2)
